description.en: TODO
Link to the metadata of the observationCollection.

The parameter describes an arbitrary event-specific parameter. This might be an environmental parameter, an instrument setting or input, or an event-specific sampling parameter that is not tightly bound to either the feature of interest or to the observation procedure.
Reference to the specification that describes the Procedure that was followed to make the Observation.
General type of the Procedure that was followed to make the Observation.
Reference to the specification that describes the Procedure that was followed the create the Sample.
General type of the Procedure that was followed to create the Sample.
Abstract class of all names in a Namespace.

usage.en: Subtypes are LocalName and ScopedName. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19103.

description.en: TM_Object is a temporal object.
Characteristic of a feature type
Identification in terms of communication with the person(s) and organization(s) related to data.
Abstract class of all possible tests to assess the quality of a dataset.

usage.en: This means a test to assess Completeness, LogicalConsistency, PositionalAccuracy, ThematicAccuracy or TemporalAccuracy.

description.en: Information about the events or source data used in constructing the data specified by the scope or lack of knowledge about lineage
Metadata is data that contains information about data.
The determination of the value of a particular characteristic of an Object at a given time or between two times.
A series of actions or steps leading to some result.

Some observations depend on other observations to provide context which is important, sometimes essential, in understanding the result. These dependencies are stronger than mere spatiotemporal coincidences, requiring explicit representation. If present, the association class ObservationContext (Figure 2) shall link an OM_Observation to another OM_Observation, with the role name relatedObservation for the target.

In many applications specimen preparation procedures are applied to the material prior to its use in an observation. The class PreparationStep shall link a SF_Specimen to a SF_Process that describes a phase of the specimen preparation.
Feature, such as a station, transect, section or specimen, which is involved in making observations concerning a domain feature

Sampling features are frequently related to each other, as parts of complexes, through sub-sampling, and in other ways. If present, the association class SamplingFeatureComplex shall link a SF_SamplingFeature to another SF_SamplingFeature. It shall support one attribute.
Spatially defined part of the Object to be observed and representative of that Object
Way in which the result of the Observation was obtained.
A Specimen is a physical sample, obtained for observation(s) carried out ex situ, sometimes in a laboratory.
Denotes a subset of a DataSet defined by fixing a subset of the dimensional values, component properties on the Slice.
The Geometry class provides the means to identify a location as a point, line, polygon, etc. expressed using coordinates in some coordinate reference system.
A collection of one or more observations, whose members share a common value for one or more properties.
A platform is an entity that hosts other entities, particularly sensors, actuators, samplers and other platforms.
An established or official way of doing something.
A device that is used by, or implements, a (Sampling) Procedure to create or transform one or more samples.
An act of Sampling carries out a (Sampling) Procedure to create or transform one or more Samples.

Device, agent (including humans), or software (simulation) involved in, or implementing, a procedure. Sensors respond to a stimulus, e.e., a change in the environment, or Input data composed from the Results of prior observations, and generate a result. Sensors can be hosted by platforms.

A workflow, protocol, plan, algorithm, or computational method specifying how to make an observation, create a sample, or make a change to the state of the world (via an actuator). A procedure is re-usable, and might be involved in many observations, samplings or actuations. It explains the steps to be carried out to arrived at reproducible results.

A workflow, protocol, plan, algorithm, or computational method specifying how to make an Observation, create a Sample, or make a change to the state of the world (via an Actuator). A Procedure is re-usable, and might be involved in many Observations, Samplings, or Actuations. It explains the steps to be carried out to arrive at reproducible Results.

The closeness of agreement between the Result of an Observation (resp. the command of an Actuation) and the true value of the observed ObservableProperty (resp. of the acted on ActuatableProperty) under the defined Conditions.
Total useful life of a System's battery in the specified Conditions.
Used to specify ranges for qualities that act as Conditions on a Systems' operation.

usage.en: For example, wind speed of 10-60m/s may be used as the Condition on a SystemProperty, for example, to state that a Sensor has a particular Accuracy under that Condition.

description.en: An observed value for which the probability of falsely claiming the absence of a component in a material is beta, given a probability alpha of falsely claiming its presence.
A continuous or incremental change in the reported values of Observations over time for an unchanging Property under the defined Conditions.
The smallest possible time between one Observation, Actuation, or Sampling and the next, under the defined Conditions.
The time between a command for an Observation (resp. Actuation) and the Sensor providing a Result (resp. the Actuator operating the Actuation), under the defined Conditions.
Schedule of maintenance for a System in the specified Conditions.
The set of values that the Sensor can return as the Result of an Observation under the defined Conditions with the defined system properties.
Power range in which System is expected to operate in the specified Conditions.
Describes normal operating properties of a system under some specified conditions. For example, to the power requirements or maintenance schedule of a system under a specified temperature range.
Describes normal OperatingProperties of a System under some specified Conditions. For example, to the power requirement or maintenance schedule of a System under a specified temperature range.

The closeness of agreement between replicate Observations on an unchanged or similar quality value: i.e., a measure of a Sensor's ability to consistently reproduce an Observation, under the defined Conditions.
The smallest difference in the value of a ObservableProperty being observed that would result in perceptably different values of Observation Results, under the defined Conditions.
The time between a (step) change in the value of an observed ObservableProperty and a Sensor (possibly with specified error) 'settling' on an observed value, under the defined Conditions.

Selectivity is a Property of a Sensor whereby it provides observed values for one or more ObservableProperties such that the Result for each ObservableProperty are independent of other Properties in the FeatureOfInterest being investigated, under the defined Conditions.
Sensitivity is the quotient of the change in a Result of Observations and the corresponding change in a value of an ObservableProperty being observed, under the defined Conditions.

An identifiable characteristic that represents the extent of the System's useful life under the specified Conditions. May describe for example total battery life or number of recharges, or, for Sensors that are used only a fixed number of times, the number of Observations that can be made before the sensing capability is depleted.
Describes survivalproperties of a system under some specified conditions. For example the lifetime of a system under a specified temperature range.

Describes normal measurement, actuation, sampling properties such as accuracy, range, precision etc of a system under some specified conditions such as a temperature range. The capabilities specified here are those that affect the promary purpose of the system, while those in operatingrange represent the system's normal operating environment, including conditions that don't affect the observation or the actuations.
Total useful life of a System (expressed as total life since manufacture, time in use, number of operations, etc.) in the specified Conditions.

An identifiable and observable characteristic that represents the System's ability to operate its primary purpose: a Sensor to make Observations, an Actuator to make Actuations, or a Sampler to make Sampling.
Features are abstractions of real-world phenomena.
Observation of a class an Object belongs to.

usage.en: Eg the taxon of a Plant. Result is a ScopedName. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19156.

description.en: Observation of a characteristic of an Object that produces a structured result.

usage.en: Eg the composition of a SoilSample. Result is a Record. For a more detailed description see ISO 19156.

description.en: Observation of some countable characteristic of an Object.

usage.en: Eg the number of votes in an Election. Result is of type Integer. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19156.

description.en: Observation of the form and/or location of an Object.

usage.en: Eg the perimeter of a Plot. Result is of type Geometry. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19156.

description.en: Observation of some quantifiable characteristic of an Object.

usage.en: Eg the mass of a Rock. Result is of type Measure. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19156.

description.en: The class NamedValue provides for a generic soft-typed parameter value.
Observation about how some characteristic of an Object varies for different points in space.

usage.en: Eg the temperature in different MeasuringStations. Result is of type DiscreetTimeInstantCoverage. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19156.

description.en: Observation of the timeframe in which an Object occurs.

usage.en: Eg the duration of a Sprint. Result is of type TM_Object. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19156.

description.en: Observation about how some characteristic of an Object varies for different points in time.

usage.en: Eg the temperature in a MeasurementStation at different times during the day. Result is of type DiscreetTimeInstantCoverage. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19156.

description.en: Observation if something is true or false about an Object.

usage.en: Eg occurence of Fossiles. Result is of type Boolean. For a more detailed description of this class see ISO 19156.

description.en: A tangible object designed to perform a particular Task
The functionality necessary to accomplish the Task for which a device is designed.
The goal for which a device is designed (from a user perspective).
System is a unit of abstraction for pieces of infrastructure that implment Procedures. A system may have components, it's subsystems, which are other Systems.
TODO
Link to the metadata of the observation.
Relation linking an Observation to the property that was observed. The ObservableProperty should be a property of the FeatureOfInterest (linked by hasFeatureOfInterest) of this Observation.

The parameter describes an arbitrary event-specific parameter. This might be an environmental parameter, an instrument setting or input, or an event-specific sampling parameter that is not tightly bound to either the feature of interest or to the observation procedure.

Phenomenon time describes the time that the result applies to the property of the feature of interest. This is often the time of interaction by a sampling procedure or observation procedure with a real-world feature.

The resultQuality describes the quality of the result. This instance-specific description complements the description of the observation procedure, which provides information concerning the quality of all observations using this procedure. Quality of a result may be assessed following the procedures in ISO 19114:2003.

The resultTime describes the time when the result became available, typically when the procedure associated wit hthe observation was completed. For some observations this is identical to the phenomenonTime. Howevere there are important cases where they differ.
Estimate of the value of a property determined through a known observation procedure
Observations of which the results are related in one way or another
The attribute role:GenericName shall describe the relationship of the target OM_Observation to the source OM_Observation.
The processOperator describes the operator of the process involved in the preparation step.
The attribute time:TM_Object shall describe the time that the SF_Process was applied to the SF_Specimen. It supports ordering of preparation steps.

The lineage describes the history and provenance of the SF_SamplingFeature. This might include information relating to the handling of the specimen, or details of the survey procedure of a spatial sampling feature.

The parameter describes an arbitrary event-specific parameter. This might be an environmental parameter, an instrument setting or input, or an event-specific sampling parameter that is not tightly bound to either the feature of interest or to the observation procedure.
References to the feature that one wants to sample.
Reference to other SamplingFeatures with which the SamplingFeature is associated.
The attribute role:GenericName shall describe the relationship of the target SamplingFeature to the source SamplingFeature.
The materialClass provides a basic classification of the material type of the specimen.
Details on how the specimen was processed.
The samplingLocation describes the location from where the specimen was obtained.
The samplingMethod describes the method used to obtain the specimen from its sampledFeature.
The samplingTime records when the specimen was retrieved from the sampledFeature.
An entity responsible for making contributions to the resource.

usage.en: The guidelines for using names of persons or organizations as creators also apply to contributors. Typically, the name of a Contributor should be used to indicate the entity.

description.en: An entity primarily responsible for making the resource.

usage.en: Examples of a Creator include a person, an organization, or a service. Typically, the name of a Creator should be used to indicate the entity.

description.en: An account of the resource.

usage.en: Description may include but is not limited to: an abstract, a table of contents, a graphical representation, or a free-text account of the resource.

description.en: An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.

usage.en: Recommended practice is to identify the resource by means of a string conforming to an identification system.

description.en: An entity responsible for making the resource available.

usage.en: Examples of a Publisher include a person, an organization, or a service. Typically, the name of a Publisher should be used to indicate the entity.

description.en: Information about rights held in and over the resource.

usage.en: Typically, rights information includes a statement about various property rights associated with the resource, including intellectual property rights.

description.en: The topic of the resource.

usage.en: Typically, the subject will be represented using keywords, key phrases, or classification codes. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.

description.en: A name given to the resource.
Geometry expressed in GML format.
Geometry expressed in WKT format

A relation between an Observation and the entity whose quality was observed, or between an Actuation and the entity whose property was modified, or between an act of Sampling and the entity that was sampled.

A relation between an Observation and the entity whose quality was observed, or between an Actuation and the entity whose property was modified, or between an act of Sampling and the entity that was sampled.
Link to a member of a collection of observations that share the same value for one or more of the characteristic properties
Relation linking an Observation and a Sensor or Actuator and a Result, which contains a value representing the value associated with the observed Property.
The simple value of an Observation or Actuation.

Link to the ultimate feature of interest of an observation or act of sampling. This is useful when the proximate feature of interest is a sample of the ultimate feature of interest, directly or transitively.

Link to the ultimate feature of interest of an observation or act of sampling. This is useful when the proximate feature of interest is a sample of the ultimate feature of interest, directly or transitively.
Relation between a Platform and a Sensor, Actuator, Sampler, or Platform, hosted or mounted on it.
Relation between a Sensor, or Actuator, Sampler, or Platform, and the Platform that it is mounted on or hosted by.
Relation between an ObservableProperty and the Sensor able to observe it.
Relation linking a Result to the Observation or Actuation that created or caused it.
Relation linking an act of Sampling to the Sampler (sampling device or entity) that made it.
Relation between an Observation and the Sensor which made the Observations.
Relation between an Observation and the Sensor which made the Observations.
Relation between a Sensor and an Observation made by the Sensor.
Relation between a Sampler (sampling device or entity) and the Sampling act it performed.
Relation linking an Observation to the property that was observed. The ObservableProperty should be a property of the FeatureOfInterest (linked by hasFeatureOfInterest) of this Observation.
Relation between a Sensor and an ObservableProperty that it is capable of sensing.

The time that the Result of an Observation, Actuation, or Sampling applies to the FeatureOfInterest. Not necessarily the same as the resultTime. May be an interval or an instant, or some other compound temporal entity [owl-time].
The result time is the instant of time when the Observation, Actuation or Sampling activity was completed.
The result time is the instant of time when the Observation, Actuation or Sampling activity was completed.
A relation to link to a re-usable Procedure used in making an Observation, an Actuation, or a Sample, typically through a Sensor, Actuator or Sampler.
A relation to link to a re-usable Procedure used in making an Observation, an Actuation, or a Sample, typically through a Sensor, Actuator or Sampler.
A relation to link to a re-usable Procedure used in making an Observation, an Actuation, or a Sample, typically through a Sensor, Actuator or Sampler.
Relation between a Procedure (an algorithm, procedure or method) and an entity that implements that Procedure in some executable way.
Relation between an entity that implements a Procedure in some executable way and the Procedure (an algorithm, procedure or method).
Relation from an OperatingRange of a System to an OperatingProperty describing the operating range of the System.
Relation from a System to an OperatingRange describing the normal operating environment of the System.
Relation from a SurvivalRange of a System to a SurvivalProperty describing the survival range of the System.
Relation from a System to a SurvivalRange.
Relation from a System to a SystemCapability describing the capabilities of the System under certain Conditions.
Relation from an SystemCapability of a System to a SystemProperty describing the capabilities of the System.
Describes the prevailing environmental Conditions for SystemCapabilites, OperatingRanges and SurvivalRanges.
Describes the prevailing environmental Conditions for SystemCapabilites, OperatingRanges and SurvivalRanges.
Describes the prevailing environmental Conditions for SystemCapabilites, OperatingRanges and SurvivalRanges.
Description of the shape and location of the SpatialSamplingFeature.
Task that the Device was designed to accomplish.
Function that the Device can perform to accomplish a Task.
Name of the manufacturer of the Device.
Name of the model of the Device.
